THE PROPOSAL  

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  proposed

II. 

THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

 
Pro-poor  growth  is  the  main  strategic  pillar  for  reducing  income  poverty  in  the  Country 
2. 
Strategy and Program for 2003–2006 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The strategy will 
support  the  high-growth  agenda  of  the  Government  of  India  (the  Government)  through 
assistance for fiscal consolidation, private sector development, and infrastructure development. 
The  power  sector  is  one  of  the  major  sectors  in  infrastructure  development  where  ADB’s 
intervention  will  be  directed  to  policy  reforms  and  capacity  building,  combined  with  physical 
investment support. ADB’s Country Strategy and Program also provides for extended coverage 
to the northeastern region, where poverty incidence is much higher than the national average, 
and where significant potential for regional cooperation exists.  
 
3. 
Recognizing  its  inability  to  fund  the  additional  investments  required  for  delivering  high-
quality power at a reasonable price, the government of Assam (GOA) has decided to restructure 
the  power  sector  to  increase  its  operational  efficiency,  delivery  capacity,  and  self-financing 
capability, and to free budget resources to be reallocated to social sectors. In March 2001, GOA 
signed  a  memorandum  of  understanding  with  the  Government  and  committed  to  reforming  its 
power sector. Based on the memorandum of understanding, GOA established Assam Electricity 
Regulatory  Commission  (AERC)  in  August  2001  and  initiated  the  reform  program  including 
energy  auditing,  computerization,  distribution profit center  approach,  and  labor  rationalization. 
To  further  proceed  with  the  reform  program,  GOA  has  requested  assistance  from  ADB 
(Appendix 1).  
 
4. 
In response to GOA’s request, ADB included the SDP in the India Country Strategy and 
Program  for  2003.  In  preparation  for  the  SDP,  ADB  approved  a  TA1 grant to advise GOA on 
design  and  implementation  of  the  restructuring  of  ASEB  and  support  ASEB  in  preparation  of 
immediately needed investment projects. ADB also approved a TA2 grant funded by the Japan 
Special Fund for capacity building of AERC to strengthen the regulatory framework and capacity 
for  the  power  sector  reforms.  An  ADB  loan  appraisal  mission  visited  Assam,  India  from  25 
August  to  15  September  2003.  This  report  is  based  on  the  agreements  reached  during  the 
mission.

6. 
Since independence, the power sector of Assam has grown based on the state’s natural 
resources of oil and natural gas and the hydropower potential of the northeast, in response to 
the  requirements  of  the  population  spread  extensively  over  a  large  geographical  area 
interspersed with a thriving tea plantation industry. However, the power sector in Assam today is 
facing a situation where, due to various constraints, operation of generation, transmission, and 
distribution  systems  is  becoming  difficult  to  sustain  at  the  desired  level.  Power  is  supplied  to 
only  950,000  households  (out  of  4.5 million)  and  per  capita  power  consumption  is  only 
104 kilowatt-hours (kWh), which is less than one third of the national average of 359 kWh.  
 
7. 
ASEB is a vertically integrated utility, fully owned by GOA, and it, exclusively, supplies 
power in the state. It has an installed capacity of 574.4 megawatts (MW) comprising 572.4 MW 
of thermal power and 2 MW of hydropower. Of the thermal capacity, 300 MW is not operational 
for reasons such as costly fuel, design problems, and inadequate maintenance. This results in a 
plant load factor of 15%, compared to the national average of 70%. ASEB’s own system meets 
only  120  MW  out  of  total  peak  demand  of  614  MW.  The  deficiency  is  being  met  by  power 
bought from central public sector undertakings (CPSUs)3 and neighboring states. Transmission 
and distribution (T&D) losses are estimated at 41% due to lack of investment and maintenance, 
and to nontechnical losses.  
 
Poor  performance  of  the  power  sector  has  also  been  a  major  impediment  to  industrial 
8. 
growth.  The  lack  of  sufficient  and  reliable  power  is  eroding  Assam’s  competitiveness  and 
prevents it from attracting industrial investments from outside the state. Improved power supply 
at a reasonable cost is, therefore, essential to revive the state’s industry and its economy more 
generally. Equally important is improving financial sustainability of the power sector so that it is 
no  longer  a  drain  on  state  finances.  The  power  sector’s  demands  on  the  state  budget  have 
resulted  in  allocation  of  public  funds  at  the  expense  of  other  state  responsibilities,  such  as 
education and health.

9. 
The power sector of Assam is faced with three major constraints that need to be urgently 
addressed: (i) significant load restrictions and system constraints, (ii) lack of accountability, and 
(iii) ASEB’s critical financial position and heavy dependence on government resources.

Critical  Financial  Position.  ASEB’s  high  cost  structure,  coupled  with  GOA-directed 
tariff setting in the past and poor billing and collection, has significantly undermined its financial 
health.  GOA, due to its critical fiscal condition, has been unable to provide adequate support to 
ASEB’s revenue gap. ASEB has defaulted on payments to most of its creditors and has found it 
difficult to raise capital in the  market in the recent times . As a result, lack of capital investments 
and poor maintenance have decayed the power system and caused the quality and coverage of 
the  power  supply  to  deteriorate.  ASEB’s  chronic  liquidity  problem  has  prevented  it  from  filling 
the supply shortage by power purchases, despite the power surplus situation in the northeastern 
region.  
  
 
 
13. 
GOA has launched a comprehensive program for restructuring  the power sector in order 
to  ensure  that  electricity  will  be  supplied  in  adequate  quantities,  in  an  efficient  manner,  and  at 
reasonable cost to all consumers in the state. GOA issued its “Power Policy Statement 2003” in 
January  this  year.  In  it,  GOA  clearly  expressed  its  commitment  to  undertake  sector  reform 
through  (i) providing  an  appropriate  legal  framework  for  reform,  keeping  in  view  the  national 
legislative framework and the interests of its people; (ii) reorganizing and unbundling ASEB into 
corporatized  functional  companies;  and  (iii) strengthening  the  independent  tariff  setting  and 
regulatory capacity of AERC. 
 
In  line  with  the  recommendations  of  an  ADB  TA, 4  ASEB  introduced  a  profit  center 
14. 
approach  in  its  14  “distribution  circles”  as  a  first  step  to  unbundling  and  corporatizing  its 
operations  in  2002.  In  all  circles,  billing  and  collection,  and  maintenance  functions  have  been 
separated  to  sharpen  focus  on  revenue  collection,  and  decision-making  authority  for  routine 
operational  matters  has  been  delegated  to  the  heads  of  the  circles.  ASEB  has  started  an 
extensive distribution modernization program covering all 14 distribution circles, with assistance 
from  the  Accelerated  Power  Development  and  Reform  Program  (APDRP)  of  the Government. 
To  further  accelerate  its  reform  efforts,  GOA  requested  ADB  assistance  to  address the three 
major issues of the power sector, namely, (i) financial distress of ASEB and increasing burden on 
the state budget; (ii) the operational and system constraints of ASEB; and (iii) low service quality 
and coverage.

ADB’s Country and Sector Strategy 

  
Operational  Strategy.  To  sustain  poverty  reduction,  the  10th  Five-Year  Plan  of  the 
15. 
Government targets a high growth rate of 8% per year, requiring a very high rate of investment. 
ADB positions its support in the power sector as a major intervention to achieve pro-poor growth 
through  infrastructure  development.  At  state  level  operations,  ADB  has  adopted  a  sector 
development program modality, recognizing that physical investment support would not contribute 
to  pro-poor  economic  growth  unless  sector  reform  is  undertaken  simultaneously.  Another 
important  challenge  in  achieving  high  growth  is  a  major  fiscal  turnaround.  ADB  is  directly 
addressing  this  issue  through  its   support  in  improving  public  resources  management.  ADB’s 
support  to  the  state  power  sector  reforms  is  also  intended  to  indirectly  support  state  fiscal 
consolidation,  as  the  power  sector  is  the  major  drain  on  the  state’s financial resources. ADB is 
supporting the power sector reforms through its state-wide operations and is aiming to ensure 
sustainability  of  the  power  sector  reform  program  through  its  long-term  interventions  in  the 
state-wide reforms, including support for the public resources management.  ADB operations in 
the  Indian  power  sector  and  coordination  with  other  major  funding  agencies  are  discussed  in 
Appendix 2 and 3.  
  
Lessons  Learned.  ADB’s  2001  evaluation  study5 on program lending identifies several 
16. 
key  factors  to  increase  the  efficacy,  sustainability,  and  development  impact  of  program  lending.

Rural Electrification Program 

 
 
 
51. 
Based on the national 5-year rural electrification plan, ASEB plans to electrify all villages 
by  2007,  and  all  households  by  2012.  The  majority  of  Assam  is  rural;  while  70%  of  all  urban 
households are electrified, less than 20% of all rural households are electrified. The impediment 
to rural electrification is not simply access to the grid. Although 19,019 of the 24,685 populated 
villages  in  Assam  are  electrified  at  least  by  a  single-point  supply,  penetration  ratios  in  those 
villages are very low. This is partly because the grid is incapable of providing reliable electricity 
to  the  rural  population  and,  thus,  rural  areas  are  actually  being  “de-electrified”.  ASEB’s  10th 
Five-Year  Plan  (2002–2007)  therefore  includes  intensifying  electrification  in  the  19,019 
connected villages to reach at least 50% household connectivity in addition to connecting 2,411 
of the 5,666 “virgin” villages to the grid by 2007. ASEB is repairing 37 substations, but another 
25 are in need of repair. Under the Project, 1,200 distribution transformers will be replaced by 
transformers  with  meters,  25  substations  will  be  upgraded,  and  a  system  study  for  rural 
electrification will be performed for optimum grid expansion planning in rural areas.  
  
Connection  charges  represent  another  impediment  to  rural  electrification  through  grid 
52. 
extension. Despite their low income levels, unconnected households in rural areas pay more for 
energy such as kerosene than households that are electrified. An ADB survey  (Supplementary 
Appendix C) has shown that at least 50% of all unconnected households, in both connected and 
unconnected villages, would immediately take electricity if it were offered and if they could afford 
the connection charges, which are estimated at about Rs3,000 per line, or more if connection 
requires erecting additional poles. This implies that subsidies should be directed at connection 
charges, rather than tariffs, in order to extend connections. This issue will be addressed by GOA 
in its new rural electrification policy.  
 
53. 
Another  important  factor  for  sustainable  rural  electrification  is  capacity  building  of  the 
stakeholders.  There  needs  be  an  effective  organization  at  the  village  level  to  act  as  the  bulk 
purchaser  and  to  provide  the  billing  and  collection  functions.  This  organization,  under  the 
oversight of a state-level umbrella organization to coordinate practices and standards, would be 
responsible for managing the local problems of connection, maintenance, theft, and collection. 
Recognizing  that  a  rural  electrification  model  has  been  very  successful  in  Bangladesh,  a  TA

Poverty and Social Dimensions 

 
The  Project  will  directly  and  indirectly  contribute  to  economic  growth  and  will  reduce 
56. 
poverty, by lowering household energy costs and by removing energy constraints to enterprises 
that offer employment opportunities for the poor. There is an association between electrification, 
higher income levels, improved health status, and educational achievements. Direct benefits will 
extend to all categories of consumers, poor and nonpoor, in improvements to the existing quality 
of supply. As 26% of households in Assam are already connected, mostly in urban areas, most 
of these new beneficiaries will be among the rural poor. The rural electrification (RE) component 
of the Project will reconnect  approximately 1,200 villages with a potential to provide connection 
to approximately 78,000 households in which about 40% live below the poverty line. In addition,

benefits to households include better quality lighting for the same outlay as they currently incur 
on kerosene, improved air quality in the home, and possible substitution of at least some of the 
prevalent fuelwood used for cooking. Of indirect general benefit will be improved public facilities 
such as street lighting, and social infrastructure such as hospitals and schools. Gender impacts 
of electrification are particularly favorable; women want electricity and have clear perceptions of 
its power to reduce drudgery, to ease working hours, to increase access to the media, and to 
enhance  the  general  amenity  in  their  lives.  A  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social 
development strategy is attached as Appendix 10.

Financial Analysis 

 
77. 
The financial analysis of the Project is presented in  Appendix 15. Because the impacts 
of  the  T&D    components  are  interdependent,  they  have  been  combined  for  the  economic  and 
financial analysis. The revenue management system component has been designed to reduce 
commercial  losses  by  providing  100%  metering,  a  computerized  billing  system,  and  prompt 
accounting of metered data. Both components exhibit a financial internal rate of return (FIRR) 
that is above ASEB’s weighted average cost of capital. The beneficiaries of the RE component 
are  former  consumers  in  villages  that  have  lost  access  to  electricity  because  of  equipment 
failures  at  the  village  level.  The  expenditure  on  this  component is primarily for replacement of 
damaged transformers. The revenues resulting from this investment will flow primarily from rural 
domestic  customers,  many  of  whom  are  not  metered  and  pay  a  flat  rate  charge  that  yields  a 
relatively  low  return  on  energy  consumed.  As  a  result,  the RE component exhibits a negative 
FIRR.

Economic Analysis 

 
The  economic  analysis  of  the  investment  program  is  also  presented  in  Appendix  15. 
78. 
Economic  analysis  was  performed  for  only  the  transmission  and  distribution  components 
combined  and  the  RE  component,  as  the  benefits  of  the  revenue  management  system 
component  are  largely  directed  at  improving  the  financial  performance  of  the  sector.  The 
economic gains from the T&D components are reduced requirements for generation of electrical 
energy that would otherwise be “lost” in the network, and increased economic activity resulting 
from  consumers’  improved  ability  to  meet  their  energy  needs  from  grid-based supplies. The 
costs  and  benefits  are  valued  in  economic  terms  and  show  a  high  economic  internal  rate  of 
return (EIRR).

required  to  reestablish  supply  in  areas  where  supply  facilities  already  exist  and  the  relatively 
high opportunity cost associated with alternative sources of energy supply. The RE component 
is an essential part of ASEB’s rural electrification plan, which is intended to bring electrification 
to all households by 2012. Before new connections can be made, the grid must be strengthened 
and  the  transformers  made  more  reliable.  The  RE  component  will  lead  to  even  greater 
economic benefits when it is followed by a project that connects rural consumers to the grid.

80. 
The  social  impact  of  the  project  components  is  measured  by  the  poverty  impact  ratio 
(PIR).  The  direct  project  benefits  include:  (i) economic  benefits  of  the  incremental  energy 
supply,  computed  based  on the estimated willingness to pay of domestic consumers, and the 
cost  of  self-generation  for  nondomestic  consumers;  (ii) the  economic  value  of  cost  savings  in 
the  production  of  nonincremental  energy  usage;  and  (iii) the  economic  value  of  the  cost  of 
producing  incremental  energy.  The  approach  also  takes  account  of  indirect  benefits,  such  as 
street lighting and other externalities provided by the RE project, and the benefits of wages to 
labor, which are only regarded as a cost in a purely financial analysis.  
 
81. 
Since  the  revenue  management  system  is  determined  to  have  only  financial,  and  no 
economic,  benefits,  the  PIR  was  not  calculated  for  this  component.  The  T&D  and  RE 
components provided benefits that consisted in the incremental energy available to the affected 
customers,  evaluated  at  the  economic  value  to  each  customer  class.  It  was  assumed  that  all 
additional capacity would be utilized and additional energy would be sold. However, neither of 
these  components  entailed  the  connection  of  new  customers.  The  T&D  and  RE  components 
also provided cost savings in producing nonincremental energy, which accrued to ASEB; these 
were regarded as social benefits that would accrue to the poor and the nonpoor, whether or not 
they are connected. The economic benefits from increased energy sales resulting from the T&D 
components accrue to urban and rural customers alike,  but only to customers who are already 
connected. The share of these benefits accruing to the poor is estimated by estimating, first, the 
proportion of connected households that are poor. A detailed calculation of the PIR appears in 
Appendix 15.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Assam:  
 
The  investment  in  power  sector  in  Assam  ultimately  benefits  poor  and  vulnerable  groups  more  than  the  nonpoor. 
About  40%  the  state’s  population  is  poor.  Around  three  fourth  of  the  population  and  more  than  90%  of  poor  are 
currently  deprived  of  the  direct  benefits  of  state’s  power  sector.  Even  among  connected  households,  a  significant 
number  are  disconnected  each  year  due  to  floods  and  poor  maintenance  of  electricity  lines.  The  Assam  State 
Electricity Board (ASEB) is currently unable to reconnect villages due to financial problems. Since the use of electricity 
in agriculture is extremely low in Assam, crop productivity is much lower in the state than in other Indian states. This 
has direct implications for the poor because improvements in crop productivity, as in the “green revolution,” lead to 
reduced rural poverty. Because of the poor quality of supply, industries in Assam have to deal with losses and higher 
costs of power, which limit the prospects of industrial development and employment growth. These too have negative 
implications  for  the  poor.  Thus  the  investment  in  the  power  sector  for  reducing  transmission  and  distribution  (T&D) 
losses,  increasing  the  ability  to  transmit  more  power,  increase  connections,  and  reconnect  disconnected  villages 
would benefit the poor immensely. It would also enhance the capacity of the government of Assam (GOA) to invest in 
more poverty reduction programs and other social services such as health and education, thus directly benefiting the 
poor.  
 
The project will help, directly or indirectly, reduce poverty by lowering household energy costs, and removing energy 
constraints  to  enterprises  that  offer  employment  opportunities  for  the  poor.  There  is  an  association  between 
electrification, higher income levels, improved health status, and educational achievements. Direct benefits will extend 
to all categories of consumer—poor and nonpoor—in improvements in the existing quality of supply. It is expected that 
more  than  half  a  million  new  consumer  households  will  be  enabled  to  connect  over  the  next  10  years  as  the  low-
voltage lines are extended. As 26% of households in Assam are already connected, mostly in urban areas, most of 
these  new  beneficiaries  will  be  rural  poor.  Direct  benefits  to  households  include  better  quality  lighting  for  the  same 
outlay  as  they  currently  incur  on  kerosene,  and  improved  air  quality  in  the  home.  Electricity  is  cheaper  for  a  given 
amount of light delivered than these traditional fuels. 
 
Short-term direct benefits may occur in opportunities in labor and contracting for supply of goods and services in the 
construction phase of the projects. There is pent-up industrial demand for power. Longer-term employment benefits 
will follow when it is easier to provide new industrial connections and quality supply to existing ones. This and more 
connections  to  commercial  consumers  will  have  direct  benefits  in  terms  of  employment  opportunities  for the many 
qualified  youths  currently  unemployed  or  underemployed.  Better  quality  power  is  a  necessary  (if  not  sufficient) 
condition to improving access to irrigation that could have a major impact on improving incomes of the rural poor, most 
of whom hold subeconomic plots of cultivable land. Indirect public benefits will be derived through public facilities such 
as street lighting and social infrastructure such as hospitals and schools.  
 
Gender impacts of electrification are particularly favorable. The lack of electricity connections and the poor quality of 
supply affects women more since they are more home-bound than men. Such a lack also increases their morbidity as 
they work in poorly ventilated kitchens with smoky biomass-based ovens (chulas), and use traditional appliances that 
require  high  physical  effort.  Women  want  electricity  and  have  clear  views  of  its  power  to  reduce  drudgery,  ease 
working hours, increase access to the media, and enhance general amenity in their lives. 
 
B.        Poverty Analysis                                     Proposed Classification: Economic growth 
 
This assessment is based on a survey of 600 households spread over several districts of Assam, and on secondary 
data from a number of sources. Over 40% of the population in the state are below the Indian poverty line, whereas the 
whole of country rate is 36%. Average annual per capita income is $212, against the Indian level of $386. The human

of  women  are  illiterate.  Only  60%  of  households  have  access  to  safe  drinking  water.  Only  10%  of  people  live in a 
reasonably  good  house.  Around  70%  of  the  workforce  is  in  low-productive  agriculture.  The  labor  force  participation 
rate in general is lower in Assam than in India on average, and more so for women.

The  proposed  project  leads  to  a  reduction  of  transmission  and  distribution  losses  and  an  addition  of  capacity  to

poor since they did not have electricity connection. This project will ease the financial burden of GOA in the power 
sector and enhance its ability to invest in the social sector.

Interviews were held with central stakeholders before the fieldwork commenced. Institutional stakeholders are ASEB, 
block offices who identify the poor, and indigenous people's development agencies. Numerous civil society groups are 
stakeholders: Mahila Samiti, water user groups, commerce and industry councils, and religious organizations. At the

were  conducted  with  the  institutional  stakeholders.  Focus  group  meetings  were  held  with  some  civil  society  and

component requires establishment of participatory village electricity user associations and this will be addressed in the 
technical assistance (TA) component for RE. 
 
D.            Gender Development 
  
Though all members of society gain from electrification, women are the major winners. They gain from better light and 
better indoor air quality where electricity is replacing kerosene and fuelwood. Their working hours are extended, but 
they themselves cite this as a benefit, since it enables them to rest during the hottest part of the day and complete 
their work in the cooler evening hours under artificial light. Time use surveys indicated that women work an average 
8.25-hour day on domestic chores alone. If these tasks must be accomplished in hours of natural light, there is no time 
for recreation or personal development. Girls work 3 hours on domestic duties, while boys work 45 minutes. Women 
expect economic benefits from the subprojects through increased employment opportunities and decreased domestic 
drudgery. Associated with adult literacy programs, introducing electricity can have a dramatic effect on women's formal 
skills levels. Women in rural Assam suffer less discrimination on grounds of gender or caste than the rest of India; with 
56% female literacy, their education status is relatively favorable. Electrification has  a major impact on their awareness 
through the mass media of the outside world, health and education issues, market forces, and other opportunities.

c. 

Rural Electrification Costs and Benefits 

The purpose of the RE  component  is  to  restore  electricity  to  some  of  the  villages  that 
6. 
have  become  “de-electrified”. The resulting reinforcement of the RE system restore electricity 
that had been enjoyed by consumers and will provide incremental volumes to meet repressed 
demand.  All  the  electricity  sales  resulting  from  the  RE  component  are  assumed  to  reflect 
incremental energy usage. Accordingly, the direct benefit of this component is measured by the 
consumers’ WTP, estimated as the average of the price of kerosene and the revenue yield per 
kWh, multiplied by a factor of 0.8 to represent a nonlinear demand curve. This underestimates 
the  economic  benefit,  because  there  are  probably  some  customers  who  substituted  kerosene 
and who would, therefore, realize the resource cost savings (i.e., the price of kerosene less the 
cost  of  electricity)  when  they  switched  to  electricity.  The  economic  benefits  of  the  RE 
component also include the indirect benefits of street lighting and other public services, which 
benefit the poor whether or not they are connected. 
 
7. 
A primary reason that the FIRR for the RE component is negative is that the revenue per 
kWh for rural domestic customers is significantly lower than that for urban domestic customers. 
At the level of usage estimated for these customers, the domestic tariff would have to be Rs3.17 
per kWh in order for the  component to exhibit an FIRR of 8%. The present RE  component will 
not  connect  additional  customers;  however,  new  connections  are  an  essential  part  of  ASEB’s 
RE  plan,  which  is  intended  to  bring  electrification  to  all  households  by  2012.  Additionally, all 
customers will be metered; this means that the existing rural domestic customers will pay the full 
tariff  for  each  kWh  consum ed. Subsidies to rural customers will be directed at the connection 
charges rather than the tariff. Accordingly, a large increase in customers is expected, who will 
purchase  electricity  at  the  tariff,  which  is  still  below  the  maximum  WTP  (as  estimated  by  the 
price  of  kerosene).  Therefore,  the  realistic  financial  prospects  for  the  RE  program  overall 
exceed  what  is  implied  by  the  calculation  of  the  FIRR  for  the  present  investment  component. 
The  EIRR  for  the  component  is  high,  derived  from  the  additional  electricity  sold  to  existing 
customers.  In addition, the RE  component  will  provide  indirect  benefits  to  all  residents  of  the 
reelectrified  villages,  through  increased  street  lighting  and  other  public  services.  This  effect  is 
included in the calculation of the PIR.

been  calculated  from  the  poverty  impact  studies  conducted  in  conjunction  with  this  document. 
None  of  the  benefits  for  nondomestic  customers  is  assumed  to  accrue  to  the  poor.  This 
component  is  assumed  to  employ  only  skilled  labor;  none  of  the  indirect  benefits  to  labor  is 
attributed to the poor. 
 

b. 

Rural Electrification 

 
The PIR for the RE component was calculated according to the same method. However, 
15. 
because this  component  was  implemented  in  rural  villages  that  had  no  electrification,  or  very 
unreliable electricity supply, there were several differences in the analysis that must be noted. 
The domestic beneficiaries of the increase in sales are exclusively rural households. From the 
poverty  impact  data,  it  was  possible  to  estimate  the  proportion  of  poor  rural  connected 
households  as  a  proportion  of  connected  rural  households.  In  addition,  RE  offers  indirect 
benefits to unconnected households, in the form of increased street lighting and improved public 
services.  These  benefits,  per  household,  are  estimated  at  20%  of  the  benefits  to  connected 
households. These benefits accrue to connected and unconnected households alike. From the 
poverty  impact  data,  it  was  possible  to  estimate  the  proportion  of  poor  rural  households  as  a 
proportion of total rural households. 
 
An RE study reported the number of customers, by customer class, that will benefit from 
16. 
the RE  component,  together  with  the  most  recent  available  data  on  their  connected  load  and 
peak  load.  However,  since  many  of  these  customers  were  unmetered,  it  was  not  possible  to 
report their actual energy usage. Therefore, for the financial and economic analysis, the usage 
by customer class has been estimated in proportion to the connected load. The result is 87.8% 
usage  by  domestic  customers  and  12.2%  by  nondomestic  customers.  The  PIR  is  25.4%.  A 
sensitivity analysis appears in Supplementary Appendix J.
